text:
We can try to ignore trade-offs, but they’re unavoidable. 

I once helped an executive team figure out their priorities. They were stuck on naming the top five projects for their IT department in the coming year. One manager was really struggling and insisted on listing eighteen “top priority” projects. I pushed her to narrow it down to five. She took the list back to her team, and two weeks later, they managed to cut it down by just one project! (I still wonder which project got the boot.) By refusing to make real trade-offs, she spread her time and effort thin across seventeen projects. Unsurprisingly, she didn’t get the results she wanted. Her mindset was: “We can do it all.” Spoiler alert: they couldn’t.

It’s easy to want to deny trade-offs. After all, they involve choosing between two things we want. Do you want a higher salary or more vacation? Finish this email or make it to your meeting on time? Get it done faster or better? Naturally, we’d prefer a “yes” to both. But the truth is, we can’t have it all.

A Nonessentialist asks, “How can I do both?” But an Essentialist digs deeper and asks, “Which problem do I want?” They make trade-offs on purpose. They take action instead of waiting for things to happen. As economist Thomas Sowell said, “There are no solutions. There are only trade-offs.”

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Trade-offs are an unavoidable reality that require deliberate decision-making to prioritize effectively.
